DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type of container and additive used in specimen collection.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to the container and additive used in specimen collection.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: An object that can be used to hold things.:A substance that is added to a system or compound to improve its characteristics.:The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place.

Concepts.definition: An object that can be used to hold things.
A substance that is added to a system or compound to improve its characteristics.
The act of gathering things together; having been brought together in one place.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: 10mL EDTA tube
EDTA/lavender top tube
Trade name for an aqueous, non-toxic tissue storage reagent that rapidly permeates tissues to stabilize and protect cellular RNA.

Concepts.definition: Trade name for an aqueous, non-toxic tissue storage reagent that rapidly permeates tissues to stabilize and protect cellular RNA.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The hue of the long-wave end of the visible spectrum, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 630 to 750 nanometers; any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation and whose hue resembles that of blood: The uppermost part, side, or surface of something.: A blood collection tube that contains a coagulant, designed for the collection of serum.

Concepts.definition: The hue of the long-wave end of the visible spectrum, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 630 to 750 nanometers; any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation and whose hue resembles that of blood
The uppermost part, side, or surface of something.
A blood collection tube that contains a coagulant, designed for the collection of serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A saturated solution of formaldehyde, water, and typically another agent, most commonly methanol. In its typical form, formalin is 37% formaldehyde by weight (40% by volume), 6-13% methanol, and the rest water. Formaldehyde provides the disinfectant and bacteriacide/germacide effects of formalin. The water content of provides a dilution of formaldehyde and the methanol content stabilizes the naturally chemically unstable formaldehyde compound.

Concepts.definition: A saturated solution of formaldehyde, water, and typically another agent, most commonly methanol. In its typical form, formalin is 37% formaldehyde by weight (40% by volume), 6-13% methanol, and the rest water.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: EDTA purple top tube
Non-additive red top tube

PermissibleValues.value: Streck Cell Free DNA BCT tubes
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Streck Cell Free DNA BCT tubes

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Streck Cell Free DNA BCT tubes
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Streck Cell Free DNA BCT tubes
K3-EDTA tubes
A blood collection tube that contains the anti-coagulant EDTA, designed for complete blood counts and blood films.

Concepts.definition: A blood collection tube that contains the anti-coagulant EDTA, designed for complete blood counts and blood films.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between yellow and blue, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 490 to 570 nanometers; any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation and whose hue is that of the emerald or somewhat less yellow than that of growing grass.: The uppermost part, side, or surface of something.: A test tube, capillary tube, or other tube designed for the collection of blood.

Concepts.definition: The hue of that portion of the visible spectrum lying between yellow and blue, evoked in the human observer by radiant energy with wavelengths of approximately 490 to 570 nanometers; any of a group of colors that may vary in lightness and saturation and whose hue is that of the emerald or somewhat less yellow than that of growing grass.
The uppermost part, side, or surface of something.
A test tube, capillary tube, or other tube designed for the collection of blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning.: A hollow cylinder, especially one for holding or conveying liquids; anything shaped like such a hollow cylinder, e.g. an organic structure having the shape or function of a tube such as channel within a plant or animal body (e.g. fallopian tube).

Concepts.definition: The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning.

A hollow cylinder, especially one for holding or conveying liquids; anything shaped like such a hollow cylinder, e.g. an organic structure having the shape or function of a tube such as channel within a plant or animal body (e.g. fallopian tube).

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Twenty Milliliter Complete Blood Count Collection Tube

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Twenty Milliliter Complete Blood Count Collection Tube
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A natural number greater than nineteen and less than twenty-one and the quantity that it denotes.: A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume.: A blood collection tube that contains the anti-coagulant EDTA, designed for complete blood counts and blood films.

Concepts.definition: A natural number greater than nineteen and less than twenty-one and the quantity that it denotes.
A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume.
A blood collection tube that contains the anti-coagulant EDTA, designed for complete blood counts and blood films.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solution of citric acid, sodium citrate, and dextrose used as an anticoagulant in the collection and preservation of whole blood.

Concepts.definition: A solution of citric acid, sodium citrate, and dextrose used as an anticoagulant in the collection and preservation of whole blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sulfur-rich glycosaminoglycan with anticoagulant property. Heparin binds to antithrombin III to form a heparin-antithrombin III complex. The complex binds to and irreversibly inactivates thrombin and other activated clotting factors, such as factors IX, X, XI, and XII, thereby preventing the polymerization of fibrinogen to fibrin and the subsequent formation of clots.

Concepts.definition: A sulfur-rich glycosaminoglycan with anticoagulant property. Heparin binds to antithrombin III to form a heparin-antithrombin III complex. The complex binds to and irreversibly inactivates thrombin and other activated clotting factors, such as factors IX, X, XI, and XII, thereby preventing the polymerization of fibrinogen to fibrin and the subsequent formation of clots.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The sodium salt of citrate with alkalinizing activity. Upon absorption, sodium citrate dissociates into sodium cations and citrate anions; organic citrate ions are metabolized to bicarbonate ions, resulting in an increase in the plasma bicarbonate concentration, the buffering of excess hydrogen ion, the raising of blood pH, and potentially the reversal of acidosis. In addition, increases in free sodium load due to sodium citrate administration may increase intravascular blood volume, facilitating the excretion of bicarbonate compounds and an anti-urolithic effect.

Concepts.definition: The sodium salt of citrate with alkalinizing activity. Upon absorption, sodium citrate dissociates into sodium cations and citrate anions; organic citrate ions are metabolized to bicarbonate ions, resulting in an increase in the plasma bicarbonate concentration, the buffering of excess hydrogen ion, the raising of blood pH, and potentially the reversal of acidosis. In addition, increases in free sodium load due to sodium citrate administration may increase intravascular blood volume, facilitating the excretion of bicarbonate compounds and an anti-urolithic effect.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An element with atomic symbol Au, atomic number 79, and atomic weight 197.: A blood collection tube that contains a gel that separates blood cells from serum.

Concepts.definition: An element with atomic symbol Au, atomic number 79, and atomic weight 197.
A blood collection tube that contains a gel that separates blood cells from serum.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A solution of citric acid, sodium citrate, and dextrose used as an anticoagulant in the collection and preservation of whole blood.: A test tube, capillary tube, or other tube designed for the collection of blood.

Concepts.definition: A solution of citric acid, sodium citrate, and dextrose used as an anticoagulant in the collection and preservation of whole blood.
A test tube, capillary tube, or other tube designed for the collection of blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A blood collection tube with a formaldehyde-free preservative which stabilizes nucleated blood cells, preventing the release of genomic DNA, and allowing isolation of high-quality cell-free DNA.

Concepts.definition: A blood collection tube with a formaldehyde-free preservative which stabilizes nucleated blood cells, preventing the release of genomic DNA, and allowing isolation of high-quality cell-free DNA.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A proprietary blood collection tube designed for venous blood collection, containing EDTA anticoagulant and a cell preservative. The EDTA absorbs calcium ions, which prevents the blood from clotting. The preservative preserves the morphology and cell surface antigen expression of the epithelial cells and leukocytes. This blood collection tube has been used for the preservation of circulating tumor cells and lymphocyte subsets.

Concepts.definition: A proprietary blood collection tube designed for venous blood collection, containing EDTA anticoagulant and a cell preservative. The EDTA absorbs calcium ions, which prevents the blood from clotting. The preservative preserves the morphology and cell surface antigen expression of the epithelial cells and leukocytes. This blood collection tube has been used for the preservation of circulating tumor cells and lymphocyte subsets.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: A common name for a group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.
Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning.: A test tube, capillary tube, or other tube designed for the collection of blood.

Concepts.definition: The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning.
A test tube, capillary tube, or other tube designed for the collection of blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A natural number greater than 2 and less than 4 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of two and one._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._A natural number greater than 7 and less than 9 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of seven and one._A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume._A brand of of test tube specifically designed for venipuncture; the tube contains a vacuum allowing it to suck blood though a needle and fill itself. The tube may contain additives to facilitate downstream processing and testing of the blood samples; the tube cap is color-coded to indicate the type of additive present.

Concepts.definition: A natural number greater than 2 and less than 4 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of two and one.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
A natural number greater than 7 and less than 9 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of seven and one.
A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume.

A brand of of test tube specifically designed for venipuncture; the tube contains a vacuum allowing it to suck blood though a needle and fill itself. The tube may contain additives to facilitate downstream processing and testing of the blood samples; the tube cap is color-coded to indicate the type of additive present.

PermissibleValues.value: 5 - 9 ml K3EDTA or Sodium Heparin tubes

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Five To Nine Milliliter Edetic Acid Tube or Sodium Heparin Tube
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._A natural number greater than 8 and less than 10 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of nine and one._A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume._The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning._A blood collection tube that contains the anti-coagulant EDTA, designed for complete blood counts and blood films._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._A blood collection tube that contains sodium heparin as an anticoagulant. This tube is used for preparing heparinized plasma, whole blood, and bone marrow specimens. It is identified by a green closure.

Concepts.definition: A natural number greater than 4 and less than 6 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of four and one.
Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
A natural number greater than 8 and less than 10 and the quantity that it denotes: the sum of nine and one.
A unit of volume equal to one millionth (10E-6) of a cubic meter, one thousandth of a liter, one cubic centimeter, or 0.061023 7 cubic inch. A cubic centimeter is the CGS unit of volume.

The acid form of edetate, a chelating agent with anti-hypercalcemic and anticoagulant properties. Edetic acid binds calcium and heavy metal ions, forming soluble stable complexes which are readily excreted by the kidneys. This results in a decrease in serum calcium levels. This agent is also used as an anticoagulant for blood specimens and is applied as a treatment of lead poisoning.
A blood collection tube that contains the anti-coagulant EDTA, designed for complete blood counts and blood films.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

A blood collection tube that contains sodium heparin as an anticoagulant. This tube is used for preparing heparinized plasma, whole blood, and bone marrow specimens. It is identified by a green closure.
